attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description: •    Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread -326 loaves, White flour +49.999 kg, Yeast +6.997 and Utto +0.736 Litres.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Bread shortfall should be recovered from the staff responsible.
•    The branch management should verify actual production before processing production in the system to avoid cases of wrong production posting leading to material variations as witnessed.
attributes.effect: •    Variation in stock items is an indication of weak stock controls. This could lead to losses at the branch

value:
•    There was wrong production posting of White bread 1.5kg hence the excess in raw materials and a shortfall in bread of 176.75 loaves. A disassemble request was done to correct this.
•    We will continue to enhance controls on all stock items.
•    I will monitor stocks in the subsequent stock takes to make sure everything align.
•    In prior audit, Poly bags had cumulative variance of +1,360 pieces, Bread stock had short fall of 5 loaves

•    Stock take was conducted on 08th April 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
Variation in stock items is indication of weak controls and improvement is needed.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that stocks controls put in place are working efficiently

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description: •    From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted across all varieties except 1500g bread as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: •    Underweight cases should be discouraged. The production team should ensure that the prescribed production parameters are adhered to at all stages.
attributes.effect: •    Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to the risk of penalties if caught by weight and measure officials

value: •    We will closely monitor the bread production processes to ensure compliance with the required weight standards.
•    Random spot checks at the branch will continue to confirm compliance.
•    In prior audit, sampled bread had underweight as follows; 400g W – 17%, 600g W – 24%, 800G W – 19% and 1.5kg – 20%.

•    Bread weight check was done from a sample selected from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to establish whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
•    Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to the risk of penalties if caught by weight and measure officials and should be addressed to caution the company.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure bread dispatched to the market meets the minimum weight standards.

attributes.title: Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.24% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.33% of the total sales. 
•    Physical damages weighed compared to Manager’s records over the same period had a variance of +30.10kg equivalent to 75.25 loaves worth Kes. 3,988.25 (using mini shop price).

Production Damages Analysis
attributes.recommendation:
•    The production team should ensure strict compliance with production processes to minimize production damages.
•    Although minimal, variation in the verification of physical damages should be discouraged by maintaining proper records and ensuring full damages disclosure.
attributes.effect: •    Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold exposing the company to a revenue loss of Kes 20,225.86

value: •    We are putting effort to make sure production damages are at a controlled level.
•    Market damages are properly controlled, the branch manager has been advised to put more effort to control Production damages and damages accountability

•    In the previous audit, there was no noted significant difference between total damages at the branch level and damages sent to ingredients damages. Total branch damages were 5,177.35 pieces while those sent to ingredients were 5,097.25 pieces.

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 34 days - 5th Mar 2025 to 7th April 2025 to determine whether production and market damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.
Production damages exceeds the desired level hence exposing the company to revenue loss.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure both Market and Production damages are maintained at the desired level.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that, Average production was 145.59 bags per day, which is 81% of the daily target of 180 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 192.74. Data transferred from the physical mixing charts to the cash flow and SAP was accurate.

The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch need to put more effort to achieve the set production target of 180 bags per day and also eliminate cases of bread borrowing.
attributes.effect: •    The branch's production capacity utilization was at 81% of the full available capacity, leaving an idle capacity of 19%. This indicates that the branch did not fully capitalize on economies of scale.

value: •    Shift cuts due to demand has led to target shortfall.
•    We schedule production based on bread demand hence the capacity utilization shortfall.

•    In the previous audit, Utto consumption stood at 100 %.
•    Average yield was 192.74 loaves per bag.
•    Average production was 152.32 bags per day this represent 84.62% of the set target of 180 bags.
•    There was accuracy of figures transferred from mixing chart summary to cash flow for the period audited.

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 34 days from 5th Mar 2025 to 7th April 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

The branch management should continue to ensure target yield is achieved by verifying data in the mixing charts vis-a-vis the actual yield.

There is still room to increase production as the branch capacity is not fully utilized..
Operations/Production Department
To confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
•    Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had a Nil variance 
•    There were five pending IOU’s amounting to Kes. 34900 as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place.
attributes.effect: •    Nil cash variance implies that adequate cash controls are in place.

value: •    This is well noted
•    Well noted, we shall maintain.
•    Verification of cash held at the cash office on 9th April 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.
The controls in place on cash are adequate
Finance Department
To confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to

attributes.title: Minishop Spot Check
attributes.description: •    Mini shop bread balance and sales proceed were properly accounted as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls in place at the mini shop were found to be adequate and are operating effectively. It is recommended that these controls be maintained to ensure continued compliance and operational efficiency.
attributes.effect: •    The operations were carried out in accordance with established standards, as evidenced by the immaterial variance observed.

value: •    We shall continue to ensure procedures are followed at the mini shop.
•    This shall be maintained
•    A spot check was conducted in the mini shop on 8th April 2025 to assess whether the operation were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.
The spot check revealed that the SOPs are adhered to.
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether the operation were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description: •    It was noted that, the total outstanding debtors amounted to KES 301,460. Of the total outstanding balances, two institutions accounted for a combined outstanding balance of KES 265,320
attributes.recommendation:
•    Sales crew and the sales representative to ensure that bread supplied is paid for on delivery for the customers without credit arrangement.
•    Follow up on institutions with credit arrangements to ensure payments terms and credit limits are adhered to.
attributes.effect: •    Outstanding route balances for customers without credit arrangement can lead to bad debts and hence financial losses.

value: •    Sales Rep to make follow up on institutions.
•    We will ensure route balance are well controlled.
•    An analysis of the route balances was done as at 9th April 2025 to ascertain the status thereof.
Route balances are relatively controlled with only customers with credit arrangement holding a significant portion (88%) of the outstanding.
Sales Department
To ensure that the company is not exposed to cases of bad debts.

attributes.title: Production efficiency analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.63 bags per production worker. 

A summary of production analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls on production workers should be maintained.
attributes.effect: •    The production efficiency achieved was 4.63, which is above the KPI, implying that production labour was well controlled.

value: •    We will maintain
•    This is recommendable and it shall be maintained.
•    In the prior audit, it was noted that the production efficiency was 4.69 bags per production worker, standard rate achieved was above the set limit.

•    Production efficiency was calculated for period of 34 days from 5th March 2025 to 7th April 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
Production workers are managed efficiently.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 97.14 crates per slicer. 

The table below illustrates the findings;
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure packers hired continue to be controlled well and maintain the efficiency.
attributes.effect: •    The packing efficiency achieved was 97.14, which is above the KPI, implying that packing labour was well controlled.

value: •    We shall continue to ensure this is maintained.
•    This is good, the branch should maintain this.
•    Slicing efficiency was calculated over a 34-day period, from March 5, 2025, to April 7, 2025, to determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.
The packing workers hired are well managed
Operations/Production Department
To determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

attributes.title: Vehicle fuel consumption
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that KDL 169U - Suba, KCH 511N - Homabay and KTWC 683X - Migosi tuktuk routes were overconsuming while KCV 784R - Kendubay, KCN 827L - Koru and KBZ 483E - Oyugis were saving fuel as per the set rate standards.

•    Mileage analysis illustration table is annexed below.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Further investigation into vehicle consumption should be conducted, and standard rates should be adjusted to align with current actual consumption levels.

•    Fuel records should be kept up to date,
attributes.effect: •    Variations in fuel consumption from the standard rates affect cost budgeting and planning.

value: •    We shall keep the records up to date
•    I shall follow up to ensure records are up to date.
•    In the prior audit, from the analysis it was found that 3 vehicles exceed the set fuel consumption standards by 25.69 litres while other vehicles fuel consumption was within the set standard.
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st March 2025 to 31st March 2025. To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
•    Variations in fuel consumption from the standard rates affect cost budgeting and planning.
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate vehicle consumption compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
